questions.text: In a patient who has completed the 3rd stage of labor following vaginal delivery, what is the minimum amount of blood loss required for her to be diagnosed with postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) in vaginal delivery is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 ml after completion of the third stage of labour.

In Caesarean section, blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract is called PPH.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be:

  • Minor (<1L)
  • Major (>1L)
  • Severe (>2L)

In most cases, the magnitude of haemorrhage cannot be assessed accurately as visual estimates are unreliable.

Note: as per the latest ACOG guidelines, PPH is defined as cumulative blood loss ≥1000 mL or bleeding associated with hypovolaemia in the first 24 hours after birth, irrespective of the route of delivery. It is added that despite the new definition, blood loss >500 mL in a vaginal delivery should raise suspicion and mandates further evaluation.

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable cause of bleeding per vaginum occurring 24 hours after delivery?
questions.solution:
Retained cotyledon is the most probable cause of late or secondary PPH i.e., bleeding that occurs after 24 hours of delivery.

Other options are causes of early PPH. 

Types of PPH include:

Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. The causes are: (mnemonic 4T)

  • Tone: Atonic PPH (80%)
  • Trauma: Traumatic PPH
  • Thrombin: Coagulopathy 
  • Tissue: retained products of conception

Risk Factors for primary PPH:

Atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Traumatic PPH:

  • Instrumental delivery
  • Episiotomy
  • Precipitate labour
  • Macrosomia

Coagulopathy:

  • Sepsis
  • IUD
  • HELLP syndrome

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include:

  • Retained parts of cotyledon or membranes
  • Endometritis
  • Abnormal involution of placental site
  • Secondary haemorrhage from caesarean section wound
  • Placental polyp
  • Infected fibroid
  • Uterine AV fistula
  • Puerperal uterine inversion
  • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH?
questions.solution:
Placenta previa does not cause secondary postpartum hemorrhage. It causes primary postpartum hemorrhage.

Types of PPH:

Primary/early: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth.

Secondary/ late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum.

Causes and risk factors for PPH:

Primary PPH Secondary PPH
Atonic PPH Traumatic PPH Coagulopathy

Primiparity or grand multiparity

Instrumental delivery

Sepsis

 Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes

Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta

Precipitate labour

 HELLP syndrome Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound

Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia

 Macrosomia IUD Puerperal uterine inversion

Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin

Prolonged labour

     Infected fibroid 

Precipitate labour

     Endometritis

     Placental polyp

The image below shows the prevention and management of PPH:

questions.text: Which of the following complications during pregnancy does not increase the risk of PPH?
questions.solution:
Oligohydramnios does not increase the risk of PPH. However, polyhydramnios can increase the risk by causing uterine atony, due to an overdistended uterus.

Risk factors for primary PPH:

Atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Traumatic PPH:

  • Instrumental delivery
  • Episiotomy
  • Precipitate labour
  • Macrosomia

Coagulopathy:

  • Sepsis
  • IUD
  • HELLP syndrome

Causes of secondary PPH:

  • Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes
  • Endometritis
  • Abnormal involution of placental site
  • Secondary haemorrhage from Caesarean section wound
  • Placental polyp
  • Infected fibroid
  • Uterine av fistula
  • Puerperal uterine inversion
  • Carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: In a patient with GDM complicating pregnancy, there was severe bleeding following the delivery of the placenta. On abdominal palpation, the fundus felt soft and later became hard on massaging. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, a soft uterus that becomes hard on massaging indicates an atonic uterus. Uterine rupture is a risk factor of traumatic PPH, not atonic PPH.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Thus, bleeding from the placental implantation site is not arrested.

GDM complicating pregnancy can cause macrosomia, which is a risk factor of this condition.

Risk factors for atonic PPH:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multi-gestational pregnancy, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/ abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.solution:
As per the latest guidelines, uterine massage is no longer a core component of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) that is performed for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Uterine massage or fundal massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin (core component of AMTSL). Hence, it is now an optional component of AMTSL that is done in patients with uterine atony as a part of the management of PPH.

AMTSL is recommended by the WHO to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Uterotonics are the most important components in AMTSL to do so.

The currently recommended components of AMTSL are as follows:

1. Injecting uterotonics within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after delivery of the anterior shoulder
  • Most important step
  • Oxytocin 10 IU im/iv infusion is the preferred uterotonic.

(Not recommended by WHO- carboprost)

 
2 Delayed cord clamping
  • Done within 1-3 mins of delivery
  • 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus
  • Prevents fetal anemia
3 Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction: Modified Brandt Andrews technique
  • The uterus is pushed upwards and backward
  • The traction of cord is downwards and forwards
4 Intermittent assessment of uterine tone Done every 15 mins for 2 hours

Note: In the event that uterine atony is diagnosed during the assessment of uterine tone, uterine massage can be performed to control PPH.

questions.text: A patient with pre-eclampsia presents with profuse bleeding after delivery. Which of the following drugs can be used in the medical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
PPH in a patient with pre-eclampsia can be treated with misoprostol. It is a PGE1 analogue used as a second line uterotonic in the treatment of PPH.

The drug of choice for PPH in normal patients is oxytocin.

Option A: Methergine and other ergot derivatives cause dangerous hypertension in pre-eclampsia.

Options B and D: Carboprost and Dinoprost cause severe hypertension in pre-eclampsia. 

Medical Management of PPH:

Drug Dose Side effects Contraindications
Oxytocin

10-40 U in 1L crystalloid

(never given as iv bolus)

 Water intoxication -
Methergine 0.2 mg Hypertension Pre-eclampsia
Carboprost 0.25 mg (8 doses max)

Diarrhoea

Hypertension

Vomiting

Bronchial asthma

Cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases
Misoprostol 600-1000 mcg

Fever

Tachycardia

 -

questions.text: In a case of atonic PPH, a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative was given every 15 mins as a uterotonic. What is the maximum number of times the drug can be administered?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose is 2mg. 

So, 2/0.25 = 8 times.

Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH that is unresponsive to oxytocin. 

Side effects:

  • Diarrhoea
  • Hypertension
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting

Contraindications:

  • Bronchial asthma
  • Suspected amniotic fluid embolism
  • Active cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases.

questions.text: As per 2017 WHO guidelines for the treatment of PPH, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Uterine massage is not recommended in PPH when oxytocin is administered
Intravenous colloids are the recommended fluids for initial resuscitation
If the PPH is not responsive to uterotonics, uterine artery embolisation is the next step
Tranexamic acid is administered early in all cases of PPH

questions.solution:
Early administration of tranexamic acid is done in all cases of PPH.

Tranexamic acid for the treatment of PPH is used as follows:

  • Tranexamic acid should be given in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.
  • Early use of iv tranexamic acid (i.e) within 3 hours of birth
  • Fixed-dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) iv at 1 mL per minute
  • If bleeding continues after 30 minutes, the second dose of 1 g iv is given

Option A: Uterine massage must be done in addition to oxytocin in all cases of PPH. This will help in the contraction of an atonic uterus. In normal patients, uterine massage is not compulsory as per AMTSL.

Option B: IV crystalloids are the recommended fluids for resuscitation.

Option C: Balloon tamponade is the next step after uterotonics.

questions.text: Following normal vaginal delivery, a patient developed PPH and lost about 700mL of blood. Her PR was 100 bpm and her BP was 100/60mmHg. What is the value and corresponding interpretation of her shock index?
questions.solution:
Shock index = 1 and it indicates significant blood loss.

The shock index is calculated as HR/systolic BP.

Here, PR=100 and systolic BP=100.

Shock Index = 100/100 = 1

Description Range of shock index
Normal value of shock index (non-pregnant) 0.5 - 0.7
Normal value of shock index in pregnant (i.e) Obstetrical shock index 0.7 - 0.8
Significant or massive blood loss 0.9 - 1.1

If the shock index is 0.9 – 1.1, it indicates massive blood loss and the need for intensive resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient was referred to the casualty from a district hospital with atonic PPH. Which of the following measures is least likely to be done?

choices.text: Use non-pneumatic anti-shock garment to stabilize the patient

questions.solution:
Using a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) is not one of the first measures for the management of atonic PPH. NASG is used to reduce bleeding and stabilize the patient for shifting to tertiary centers. 

The below image shows a non-pneumatic anti-shock garment.

Non-pneumatic anti-shock garment (NASG) works by applying circumferential counterpressure. It decreases blood flow to the abdomen, pelvis, and lower extremities. It increases the blood flow to the heart, lungs, and brain.

First step measures in the management of PPH must be done immediately and simultaneously. This includes:

  • Continuous iv oxytocin infusion
  • Fundal massage and bimanual uterine compression
  • Volume resuscitation with crystalloids
  • Insertion of Foley’s catheter to monitor urine output
  • Alert the anesthesia team to begin a manual exploration of the uterus under GA to check for:
    • Retained placental fragments
    • Uterine abnormalities
    • Lacerations
    • Rupture
  • Blood transfusion should be done if vitals are still unstable

If bleeding still continues, further steps are taken depending on the patient profile:

  • Balloon tamponade
  • Surgical methods:
    • B lynch compression sutures
    • Uterine artery ligation
    • Internal iliac artery ligation
    • Angiographic embolization
  • Hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old multipara with atonic PPH continues to bleed profusely despite medical management and tamponade. Which of the following methods cannot be used to reduce bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thermal endometrial ablation is a treatment modality for Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB). It is not used in the treatment of PPH.

In patients who are unresponsive to initial resuscitation and medical management, the following methods can be used:

  • Balloon tamponade
  • Surgical methods:
    • B lynch compression sutures
    • Uterine artery ligation
    • Internal iliac artery ligation
    • Angiographic embolization
  • Hysterectomy.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. It is used in uterine tamponade in patients with atonic PPH who are unresponsive to medical management.

The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

It acts by stimulating uterine contraction and direct hemostatic pressure to the open uterine sinuses (tamponade effect).

The maximum capacity of the balloon is 500mL. It is inflated with normal saline (200-500mL) and can be retained for up to 12 hours. Success rates are high and it can be used to avoid hysterectomy.

Other options: Sengstaken Blakemore tube, condom catheter, and 34F Foley with 60mL balloon are other instruments that can be used for uterine tamponade.

The image below depicts Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The image below depicts Foley's catheter.

questions.text: What is the capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH?
questions.solution:
The capacity of balloon tamponade to arrest PPH is 300 to 500 mL.

Bakri balloon is used in uterine tamponade in cases of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management.

Insertion of Bakri balloon requires three team members.

  • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure. 
  • Another member places the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilizes it. 
  • The third member instills fluid to inflate the balloon.

Initially, rapid infusion of at least 150 mL of normal saline is done. It is followed by further infusion over a few minutes up to 300 to 500 mL.

questions.text: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage. 

Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers.

Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures).

Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.text: A pregnant lady delivered her baby unattended while she was on the way to the hospital. While examining her, you note a perineal tear in which the anal sphincter is disrupted. This tear is classified as___.
questions.solution:
The perineal tears in which anal sphincter is disrupted are classified as third-degree perineal tear.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: Identify B lynch suture from the image given below.
questions.solution:
Image 1 depicts B lynch suture. 

All these stitches are types of uterine compression sutures. They used to surgically oppose the walls of the uterus to arrest bleeding in case of atonic PPH.

questions.text: A patient with severe PPH is shifted to the emergency OT for B lynch compression sutures. Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

choices.text: The suture loops over the fundus
Uterine ischaemic necrosis is a complication

questions.solution:
The procedure is B-lynch compression sutures and it is used in atonic PPH. 

B lynch suture is a technique to arrest hemorrhage in severe postpartum atony.

The suture bites are taken over the lower uterine segment anteriorly. Then it is looped over the fundus to go posterior. Another bite is taken posteriorly. Then it is looped back over the fundus and taken anteriorly. The final bite is taken over the lower uterine segment and the free ends are tied in a surgical knot.

The uterus is compressed antero-posteriorly.

The success rate is high.

Ischaemic uterine necrosis is a complication of this procedure.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Cervical tear is the most common cause of traumatic PPH
  2. The vulva is the most common site for pelvic hematoma
  3. The pudendal artery is the most common artery involved in vulval hematoma
  4. Hematomas of >3cm must be surgically explored under general anesthesia
  5. Lower uterine segment rupture causes infra-levator hematoma
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 3 are true.

Statement 4: Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Larger hematomas need to be explored surgically. 

Statement 5: Lower uterine segment rupture causes supra-levator hematoma.

Types of pelvic hematomas:

Feature Infralevator hematoma Supralevator hematoma
Incidence Common Rare
Location Below the levator ani Above the levator ani
Causes Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal/ perineal tears or episiotomy wound Extension of cervical laceration, lower uterine segment rupture
Presentation Severe pain with rectal tenesmus Unexplained shock with features of internal haemorrhage
Treatment Small hematomas can be conservatively managed with cold compress Laparotomy

questions.text: In a patient with hydramnios complicating pregnancy, the third stage of labour was managed by applying fundal pressure and controlled traction of the cord. On palpation, the uterus was still soft and boggy. Within a few minutes, there was moderate bleeding per vaginum following which a reddish-purple mass was expelled. The patient then developed hypotension, bradycardia and went into shock. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.

Hydramnios is a risk factor for uterine inversion due to uterine over-distension. Fundal pressure while the uterus is atonic (soft, relaxed, and boggy) causes uterine inversion. It results in haemorrhage followed by complete uterine inversion protruding out of the vulva. Neurogenic type of shock develops due to stretching of the infundibulopelvic ligament and the ovaries.

Option A: Amniotic fluid embolism causes cardiac arrest, acute hypoxia and severe haemorrhage.

Option B: There was only moderate bleeding per vaginum and soft uterus. But since there is protrusion of the uterus per vaginum, the most probable diagnosis is uterine inversion.

Option D: Placenta accreta rarely causes uterine inversion.

Uterine inversion is an extremely rare but life-threatening complication in the 3rd stage of labor, in which the uterus is turned inside out partially or completely.

Causes:

  • Most common cause is mismanagement of 3rd stage of labour
  • Spontaneous
  • Placenta accreta (rarely)

Features:

  • Shock immediately after delivery
  • The degree of shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding
  • Shock is either neurogenic or hemorrhagic
  • Per abdomen examination - fundus of the uterus is not palpable. 

Management of uterine inversion:

Vaginal operations Abdominal operations Hydrostatic method
Kustner Huntingtons O Sullivan
Spinelli Haultain Oguch

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is the most potent drug to control PPH.

Though oxytocin is the most commonly used drug for the prevention and treatment of PPH, Carboprost is highly efficacious than oxytocin in treating PPH. If the question would have been "Drug of choice to treat PPH" then the answer will be Oxytocin. 

Drug

Use in PPH

Oxytocin

DOC to prevent and treat PPH

Methergin

Drug to prevent and treat PPH

Carboprost(PGF2)

Best drug to control PPH

Misoprostol(PGE1)

2nd line drug to treat PPH

Initially for PPH, oxytocin or methergin (ergometrine) is given. If it fails to control the bleeding then Misoprostol is given.
